Bottle - Bottle - Pours hazy choc ruby brown. Choc, caramel malt aromas together with some slight citrus. Not as roasty as I was expecting, very smooth, slight sweetness followed by a nice dry hop finish.

Bella bella davvero ne mio bicchiere, uno splendido color tonaca di frate, con schiuma color cappuccino densa e abbondante. Al naso tanta frutta scura, e cioccolato. In bocca molto equilibrata, pulita e appagante, con un pò di corpo in più sarebbe da capogiro.
UPDATED: OCT 23, 2011 Bottle, pours, black with big brown head. Aroma is fruits, caramel and chocolate. Taste is medium sweetness. Good !

Mikkeller Jackie Brown is almost black American Brown Ale with good head.
Aroma has lots of citrus, pine and exotic fruit. Theres slight touch of roasty coffee too.
Flavor has same elements being more like a hoppy IPA, than Brown Ale. Ok, theres that same roasty coffee with chocolate. Aftertaste is bitter and slighly sour.
Mouthfeel is heavier than beers with this abv usually. Afterall Jackie Brown is a very hoppy beer for brown ale. I guess this is yet again one of those beers that you cant categorize (like Nögne #100). But still, Its pretty damn good beer to me.
50cl bottle. Pours pitch black with a big brown head. Smells sur. Tastes sur, smoky with a similar finish. Probably infected.

Dark brown, big tanned head. Smells of ripe fruits and caramel, also some chocolate. Taste is medium malty with å tiny hint of sweetness. Dry oily mouthfeel. Very intense bitter finish. Å very fine beer

Bottle.....666 # pours dark brown with medium fluffy,creamy tan head.... the aroma is caramel, hops.......the flavor is light bitter, hoppy, caramel, licorice..... medium body..... it takes brown ale to an higher level ! :) ..... well made Mikkeller ! thx.....

Bottle. Pours a murky brown with a tan / off-white head. Aroma of light malt, roasted nuts and floral notes. Flavour of toasted malts, roasted nuts, florally and lightly soapy. Medium-bodied, roasty, bitter, quite thin.
En god öl från danmark som vi tyckte mycket om. Lättdrucken men inte så intressant.

500mL bottle, split amongst several of us, pours an opaque reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma of light roasted malt, toasted nuts and some floral notes. Flavour of toasted nuts, roasted malt, light buttery caramel and some floral notes. A little thin and averagely complex. Standard, but enjoyable.
Bottiglia da 33 comprata su Birraland da Gian e Giulia (grazie!) e abbinata con i brownies. Buona, bella caffettosa!

Aroma is strong and malty with an overtone of caramel and molasses plus a surprising and rather firm hoppy note. It pours a semi-transparent cola brown with at thick and rather persistent light tan head that leaves a fair amount of lacing. Flavor is rich and malty with caramel and brown sugar notes and a hoppy, earthy, slightly tinny undertone. Medium-bodied texture has a good fizz that leaves a slight tingle and a malty, hoppy, tinny finish.

Bottle 500 ml. A clear dark brown colour with a medium high tan head. An aroma of roasted malt, caramel, coffee and citrus. The taste is medium bitter. A medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation and a long finish.
Bottled. Brown colour, small beige head. Aroma is barnyard, herbs, weak roast and some malts. Flavour is malts, hops and some gingerish and spicy notes. Lots hops.

Dark brown color with tan head that persist. Strong american hop aroma with citrus and dark chocolate / roasted hints. Malted chocolate and dark malts flavor, mild in the after taste with some coffee notes. Excellent beer, all flavours rounds up to give a balanced and flavofull malted beer.

330ml bottle. Pours an opaque chestnut, with a large beige head, which lasts well, leaving good lacing. Mild coffee blends nicely with some nutty notes to create an appealingly dark and malty aroma. Mild hops are present initially, giving some herbal and pine notes to the beer. These give way to a smooth, mouth-coating body, which offers rye bread, hazelnut and cream notes which flow into a coffee finish. A decent brown ale, this one. As befits the style, it doesnt try to be an out-there beer, it is simply an honest, and delightfully smooth, dark session ale.

50 cl bottle. BBE 25.02.2012.
Originally rated on 20100912. (8+5+8+3+15)
Pours deep dark red colour with extra large beige foamy head, leaves lacing. Aroma is sweet caramel malts, toffee, mild fruitness, roasted malts, loaf bread and yeast. Flavour is mildly bitter roasted malts, sweet caramel, ashy mocha and coffee with notes of nuts at the end. Bitter and somewhat sweetishly slick palate with mouth-drying finish. Medium to full-bodied. Very balanced brew which could do a bit better with richer body and higher ABV.
5425

Mörkt brun med stort skum. Lätt doft av choklad och amarillohumle. Relativt fyllig, med en chokladmaltig len smak som matchas av en trio humlen där framförallt den senare ger sin karaktäristiska lätt parfymerade smak och lämnar en lång relativt besk eftersmak. En välavvägd och mycket drickvänlig brown ale.

500ml bottle at 5,9%ABV.
Pours a medium copper, with a beige head.
Very hoppy aromas, roasted malt, spruce, faint smoke, ashes, mint.
Dry, medium bodied, medium bitterness, balanced CO2.
Fruity, hoppy taste, grapefruit, spruce, yeast, ashes, roasted malts, quite herbal.
This is more lika a lighter Black IPA, the opulent hoppiness places this beer way out of style for a proper Brown Ale. Still, not bad at all. (2011-08-19)

500 ml bottle from Systembolaget. Dark brown, mahogany, clear liquid with medium to big tan head. Aroma is hoppy and roasty with notes of grapefruit, apricot, coffee, caramel and roasted malt. Taste is dry, medium bitter and roasted. Lots of coffee notes. Light to medium bodied with nice carbonation. A bit watery. Overall, nice smelling but a bit of a disappointment when you actually put it in the mouth. Not bad though.

Bottle. Dark brown with a huge puffy beige head that settles to a half inch. Aroma has toffee, grapefruit, pine. Taste has chocolate, caramel, mild roasted malt, coffee, bitterness thats plainer than suggested by the hop aromas. Bitterness kicks in before the malt has a chance to say much at all; hop aromatics are dulled by the malts. An irritating wastrel of a beer.

Kaffeeröstiger Geruch mit deutlichen Fruchtspuren von Weintraube. Malziger, halbsüßer Antrunk. Im Mittelteil kräftiger röstig, Gleichzeitig auch fruchtig-trocken. Man erahnt Weintrauben und vielleicht auch Wacholder. Sehr angenehm. Energisch röstiger und kaffeebitterer Abgang. 
Ein sehr ausdruckstarkes Bier. Voll gelungen!Test vom 13.11.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche
smooth dark beer from everyones favourite danes. creamy head. chocolate notes.

Cloudy brown with a great big head. Fresh hops with citrus notes, light caramel, malt and chocolate in the smell. Fits me perfect with all the hops! A touch of licorice, coffee, hops and nice malt flavours in the taste. Great balance. Light to medium bodied with a distinct bitterness. Nice!

Super hoppy aromas of citrus, orange pith and pine over a lightly toasty coffee and caramel malt backbone. Really well balanced, harmonious! Flavours are hops upfront, juicy and tropical with a hint of menthol, then caramel, nutty and milk coffee malt character. Creamy mouthfeel and moderately bitter/roasty finish. Seamless balance, great drinkability, fantastic brown.
Nice dark, ruby red colour. Smells hoppy, grapefruits.. lovely. Tastes hoppy bitter and fruity. The beer is a little bit watery and it could use more body for me. Good beer though.

Bottle @ home shared with DutchDrebus. Medium red color, beige, very rough head. Smell very fruity, grapefruits, mango peach and sweetness. Lightly watery texture, misses a little body. Taste lightly coffee, mostly bitter and fruit. Decent carbo.

Tap: Dark brown color with a beautiful cappuccino-colored head. A very massive aroma of coffee, chocolate and spicy hops hits your nose. Chocolate, coffee, caramel and lots of hops with notes of grapefruit and pine fills the mouth. Very creamy texture. A very bitter Brown Ale, with a nice long lingering roasted and hoppy finish. The best Brown Ale, Ive had - so far.

Aroma: Chocolate fudge, grapefruit, apricot, cinnamon.
Taste: Banana Kids, grapefruit peel, chocolate fudge, hazelnuts.
Mouthfeel: Medium body, robust, dry finish with a lingering bitterness.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2011 Bottle (vintage 2007?) @ Pikkulintu. Originally rated on 6.3.2010. 8-4-8-4-16 = 4.0 

Re-rated on 24.7.2011. 2009(?) bottle from Alko Arkadia, BBE 25/02/12. Pours dark brown with a foamy head. Aroma has notes of hops, roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Taste is quite chocolatey with notes of coffee and roasted malts. Roasty and slightly bitter finish. Nice, well balanced brown ale.

Bottle 33cl, a dark beer with huge brownish head and good lacing. Nose is on roasted malt and roasted barley like with lemony hops. Aroma is chocolate like, not too sweet, not too astringent, nice caramel and coffee notes, very easy drinkable, nice hops bouquet, well balanced beer. Finish is on grassy hops with brown bread / chocolate aftertaste, good.

Hazy brown, creamy tan head. Nose of piney citrusy grssy hops, some smoke. Taste bold malt, prunes, pears, molasses, some spiciness. Roasty/spicy bitterness, balanced by prominent caramel aftertaste. great balance of strong flavours.

Appearance: Dark chestnut brown, slightly hazy. Good amount of tan head.
Aroma: Dark malt, dark fruit. Slight bacon.
Taste: More malt, some hops. More bitter than most brown ales.
Info: 330ml bottle, 9/7-2011

It does what it says on the label. Its brown alright with russet and rosy notes. Cream coloured head that endures and leaves good lace. Excellent nose: brown malt and crystal malt, rose petals and mandarin flesh. Very sexy.
Its got burnt caramel at first, second and third takes and then subtle chocolate and citric tartness. Its this tartness that carries on toward the finish and leaves an enduring kiss. It isnt like any other brown ale Ive had before. This is gorgeous.

Bottle purchased at Zyn in Calgary. Pours this wonderous chocolate brown colour, white a massive foamy tan head at least three fingers worth. Leaves spider-web like lacing thats just awesome. Aroma is like a little bit of cold coffee and malt, with a little bit of chocolate. Taste is just awesome. Its reminds me of a belgian ale but without the yeast and sweet. There is a little bitterness, but mainly coffee, chocolate, caramel, maybe some vanilla too. Really nice mouth feel. Smooth.

Bottle:
Vast light tan head on top of a dark brown colored beer.
Smell hops, darker fruits and spices, bitter, citrus.
Taste hops, malts, caramel, light vanilla, hops, light lactic, herbs and spices.
Nice bitter herby aftertaste.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, medium body and light watery/creamy texture.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Super light brown head. Dark color. Nose is spiced with hops: spruce, hay, chocolate - nice. Very nice palate with a fine hoppy harmony. Taste is light chocolate, hay, a bit watery. Very good na.
(Bottle 17/6-2011) Lasting light brown head, dark red color, very complex taste. Very good brown ale.

Dark brown pour with a small beige head.  Aroma was lightly roasted malts, some cocoa and light coffee notes.  Very standard.  Flavors were also lightly roasty, decent bitter finish, earthy hops all over.  Not a bad brown but nothing too exciting.

Bottle @ home. Fairly dark brown appearance with a pretty foamy tan head. Pretty tame, lightly nutty, brown malty nose. Well carbonated, slightly piney hoppy, lightly nutty, lightly oaty, brown malty flavor. Smooth, easy drinking beer.

On tap at Café Langebro, Copenhagen. Dark brown, hazy colour with a thick beige frothy head. Malty/hoppy aroma with roasted, caramel and nutty notes. Taste carries roasted coffee, chocolate and flowers. Long bitter finish, with a full body. A very good beer!

BIg brown head,
Strongly carbonated.
Lots of chocolate in aroma as well as in taste. A small taste of fruits such as citrus.
Aftertaste is a bit fruity and longlasting.
0.5l bottle, Systembolaget, Malmö.

Clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, nuts and rather hoppy - citrus. Flavor is medium sweet and rather bitter. Dry and bitter finish. Not really a brown but very enjoyable never the less. 060210
Pitch dark brown beer with a light brown creamy head. Aroma of coffee, caramel and some honey. Very hoppy and bittersweet flavour, aside of coffee. Interesting enough.

Bottle. Dark brown, average and mostly diminishing head. Moderate, malty and lightly sweetish aroma, coffee and some chocolate, herbal  piney hoppyness, some roastiness. Body is medium, malty and lightly sweetish flavor, coffee and some chocolate, some herbal  piney hoppyness and roastiness. Finish is average, malty and dryish, coffee and piney hoppyness. Really nice dryish brown ale with piney hoppyness and not too much coffee.

Malziger Antrunk, deutlich im Vordergrund ist zudem der Hopfen. Sehr aromatischer Geschmack, nicht übertrieben, ausgewogen. Aromatisch hopfig, mittelwürzig, im Abgang duetlich kräuterartig, herb. 13/12/12/12//12

Mikkeller 
Jackie Brown
For what it is worth I am an unabashed Mikkeller fan, but this comes up a little short. Pours darker brown with a reddish edge. Medium tan head and good retention. Aroma is mild roasted caramel malt with a slight brown sugar edge. Nutty and nice to smell. Flavor is a good brown ale, but not a ton. Mild hop note on the aftertaste, with some decent nutty maltiness., Clean finish and easy drinking, but not a standout.

Huge brown head. Deep dark red body with strong carbonation. Roasty dusty chocolatey aroma with citric tropical fruit notes. Dry-sweet-acidic roasty pine needle taste with burnt chocolate and earth notes. Light body. Mild mouthfeel. Dry-sweetish roasty caramelly aftertaste with burnt fruity notes. Nice, but probably a little spoiled by light infection. (0.5l bottle, Systembolaget, Charlottenberg.)

Pours out a clearish brownish ruby.  Big off-tan head, fluffy and lace-full.  Aroma is sweet, kinda chocolaty and subtly of coffee beans, with a hint of mousse.  Taste is Brown Ale-tastic.  Big wave of brown malts starts it all with, as on the nose, a subtle combo of chcolate mousse and coffee beans.  I can detect some hop bitterness, but it is overall so mild and sweet that I cannot pinpoint it.  Not too sweet to turn me off, nor too full bodied to be imposing.  Nice full-medium body with a sweet middle and off-sweet end.  Perfect Brown Ale, frankly.

0.5l bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. Pours a deep brown body with a big everlasting dense and really fluffy off-white head leaving beautiful lacings. Really light and easy aromas: distinct hopy, notes of fruits, chocolate and dark malts. Medium bodied, slick and easy, carbonation is quite lively. Nice tastes. Slightly acidic, good amount of dark malts and a round and hopy finish that continues in a longlasting chocolate-like aftertaste. Really nice brown ale this!

500 ml bottle. Dark brown. Not easy to tell whether this beer is clear is not. Tall light beige creamy head that clings to the glass. Nutty and peppery aroma with a note of roasted coffee. Some yeast as well. High carbonation level. Malty flavours with a lot of biscuit and raisins. Roasted malts. Rather lively, but quite complex and enjoyable.

Bottle consumed with Urbain at the schoolhouse. Thanks for opening this up!...Medium brown pour with good retention and lacing..The aroma is a nice combo of coffee and chocolate with nuts, good balance...The taste is very roasted, lots of coffee again. Nutty presence takes a back seat an becomes a little one dimensional, although the roasted coffee is good.

A solid brown.

Nose is kind of earthy and hoppy on top of caramel, toast, a little dusty yeast, and a hint of chocolate and tofee. Pours murky brown, huge creamy frothy head with super sticky lace. The flavor is somewhat caramelly, lightly roasty with hints of sugars, toffee, caramel, earthy hop bitterness in the finish and dusty yeast. Airy carbonation. Light lingering bitterness.

Dark ruby-brown with huge, creamy, lasting head. Aroma is soft caramel with a bit of coffee, very pleasant. Taste is bitter coffee with a little bit of citrus sour. Easy to drink, a bit thin to my liking, but I love beers with coffee touch.
Big lasting head. Aroma is coffe, spices, hops and some dried fruits maybe. Taste is roasted, sweet, malty, coffee, american hops and well balanced. Very drinkable.

Pours a dark mahogany with a light tan, almost white head. Big head, good lacing.
Hops! Simcoe is really growing on me, and this beer is a great use of them. Little citrusy, and floral bouquet outshine the slight malty aroma.
Hoppy again. The hops really coat the mouth and linger throughout the entire drink. But this is a good thing here. It doesnt annoy with the loitering hop character, just makes you want to take another sip to see if it is real. Slightly sweet.
Slightly thin. But I dont know if I would like it to be thicker. It fits the taste profile, which might get overpowered if it were to have any more body. The sweetness would also be amplified.
I could almost drink this all day. It is good, but I would want to change it up from the hoppiness that this beer displays. Now on a cold winter night, I may want to drink more than a few in a session.

500ml Bottle - Dark brown with a foamy head. Hoppy and chocolatey aroma with hints of toffee and pine. Hoppy, chocolatey and roasted taste with notes of coffee, roasted malt, milky chocolate and soap.
Bottle split with dbarnold. A really nice brown ale, with a surprisingly light body.
really really good brown, complex body and great mix of hop, coffee, roasted malt.  Drinks pretty easy and well balanced.  highly recommended

Deep brown colour with foamy off-white head. Strikingly hoppy with some chocolate, herbs and floral notes. Also a hint of coffee. A lot of roasted malts too. Creamy, medium carbonated mouthfeel. Dry, bitterish aftertaste. I dont think that Jackie Brown in the film was as bitter as this ale.
Brown colored brew. Chocolate aroma, roast. Flavor has chocolate, roasted malts, nuttyness, some citrussy hops in the end. Ok beer.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2014 Bottle. Dark brown body with a big tanned head. Roasted aroma with coffee, earthy hops. Taste of roasted malt, licorice, toffee, mild spicy. Clean and dry, good bitterness, with an aftertaste of burned malt.

Pours a beautifully clear dark brown with great looking ruby highlights when held to the light. Fluffy tan white head sticks lace wherever it touches. Smells of chocolate, caramel and sweet malts, a bit nutty as well. Smells divine for this malt head. Taste is roasty chocolaty, and nutty. In the middle is a strange astringency, then a finish of hop bitterness and roast. The middle kills this one for me. Seems like a hop attribute, and feels really out of place for me. Medium body, oily sticky mouthfeel, ample carbonation. Id love it to taste like it smells, I cant recommend this one.

Black, with a thick, longlasting moccacoloured head
Aroma; chocolate, passionfruit, fresh hay, swett/sour malt
Flavour; good bitternes, hop really dominating, not the malt you get on the nose. Medium lenght, medium - body. Nice carbonation.
Summary; an okey beer, but he makes a whole lot better beer than this. A hop-head brown ale. Almost a brown ipa

Bottle 500ml @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours dark brown with a hugh creamy off-white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate and fruity hops. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

50 cL bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in an English pint. Pours clear chestnut with a moderate pillowy tan head. The head mostly remains and leaves a large amount of fine lace. The nose has big notes of hops, caramel and molasses, along with toasted malts, coffee and anise. The flavour is moderately-intensely bitter with a complex hop bouquet, balanced against a moderate roasty maltiness. The finish is long and hoppy bitter with a touch of acidity. On the palate, it is medium in body with a smooth, milky texture and moderate, biting carbonation. Overall, this is a very well made brown ale with an intense dose of hops. It is more acidic and bitter than any other brown ale I can recall, but the package all fits together well. A hopheads brown ale. 2011-01-26

Bottle from Systembolaget. Ive been wanting to try this for a while now and finally got around to doing it. First of all, the aroma. For a brown ale it is very hoppy, not that surprising for a Mikkeller brew though, and I love it! The caramel and chocolate malts are also there, teasing the nose with their presence. It pours a murky brown colour with a thick foam that leaves a lot of lacing, again, the mind turns to chocolate. The taste is sweet and hints of coffee and chocolate from the malts and finishes off with a nice, round, hoppy bitterness in the ending. This is undoubtedly the best brown ale I have ever tried and one of my favorite beers so far, very drinkable.

Pours a dark brown a large tan head. Some nice lacing there. Aromas of coffee, hops, nuts, roasted malts. Easy drinking. A big coffee flavour with a fair bit of hoppiness giving it a dry nutty finish. Very good brown ale to say the least

50cl bottle. Poured dark brown color with a nice tan head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt and coffee. Flavor is caramel, coffee and some roastedness. Finish contains cocoa and coffee and is quite dry. Excellent beer.

Poured a very dark brown color with a huge, thick off-white head from the 750ml bottle. Aroma is hoppy, dry, toasted, roasted malts. Flavor is pine, roasted malts, nutty. This was pretty good, highly drinkable (I had no problem finishing the bottle myself).

Dark brown pour with a big foamy tan head.  Notes of light coffee, nuttiness, and big roast profile.  But there was a distinct brettiness to it.  Very dry a and semi bitter hop, almost vinegary finish.  Im guessing this was an infected bottle, due to the fact that no one else seemed to mention those issues.  Still quite quaffable, but that brett detracted from the overall.

Bottle:pours a muddy chocolate brown with a tan whispy head.smoked wood,roasted chocolates,nuts,coffee on the nose. Bitter biscuits, roasted malts,hops with a soft bitterness through a long pleasant finish. Quite light and fluffy mouthfeel.nice balance.solid

330ml bottle from Sliterij Van Bergen, Eindhoven NL!
The beer in glass is deep black, opaque with a fine, dense creamy head. Smells intense roasted malt and bitter coffee. Starts breathtaking. Roasted malt, coffee, bitter, chocolaty-caramel, a true diversity of flavors. A slightly sweet note is in background, but the coffee-like bitterness dominates along with the chocolate. The aftertaste reveals bitter coffee with a sweet aftertaste. The further course is very bitter chocolatey. Ends bitter dry!

On the Eleventh Day of Christmas the Beer Gods gave to me...  a tasty brown ale.  I once told Damico "I dont get brown ales."  His response: "You havent tried the right ones."  He was right.  This is yet another brown ale that I can sink my teeth into.  For the record no one makes brown ales quite like Cigar City, but this brew is solid.  It makes me want to throw Resevoir Dogs (or Jackie Brown) in the DVD player.  Anywho, on to the rating.  Pours a deep amber brown color with a soapy white head.  Has an aroma of caramel, coffee, and dark fruit, with hints of chocolate.  Has a roasty caramel sweet taste with a gentle bitter layer and some chocolate and coffee notes through the finish.  Thin to medium mouthfeel.

Almost black beer with big and beige head. Aroma is very temptating and aromatic, lots of roastiness with balancing full of fruitfull hoppy aromas. Citrusfruits, roastiness, some chololate and coffee. Nice, smooth and esy to drink. Flavour is roasted, black coffee, some citrusfruits and drying bitterness. Great aroma, unfortunately, taste is slightly too light; still succesfull, tastefull and enjoyable, roasted, coffee beer.

Bottled. Dirty brown colour, frothy head with lasting creaminess. Aromas of dry, toasted and slightly coffeyish-chocolatey malt and a hint of ashy. Rich hoppy aroma of piney and fruity American varieties. Dry and clean malt taste, finishes slightly nutty with crisp bitterness. Medium bodied, bitterish palate with sticky some sticky roughness of burnt malts. Enjoyable, rich and very palatable beer full of character.
Excellent brew again. the description says it all so I concentrate on enjoying.

750 ml bottle from Wine and Cheese Place.  Pours a muddy brown color with a massive beige head that laces the glass.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, chocolate and roasted malts, light coffee, citrus, floral hops, and grains.  Flavor of Belgian yeast, clove, bready and roasted malts, floral and perfumey hops, licorice, and light chocolate and coffee late.  Medium-bodied, with a bready mouthfeel and abundant soft carbonation.  This isnt a typical brown ale, more of a Belgian-style brown ale.  Not bad.

Appearance: a lovely clear brown which resembles the precious stone, tigers eye. Fluffy khaki head fades in the shape of a doughnut, her sides sticking to the glass. Creamy mousse-like consistence. Solid collar of lace.

Nose: nuts, chocolate, and toast all roasted to crispy crunchy perfection. Hops in the back with a hint of greenness; green grass and green bark. Raisins. Light and airy essence. Brittle chocolate bars and soft chocolate cake complement each other. Nuts crunchy while hops soothe.

Palate: fantastic! Grabs top of my tongue and doesnt let go not even once until of her brown beery nectar has vacated my glass for my tummy. Tons of chocolate; cake, graham crackers, truffles (powder), bars, nibs. Hops provide an exquisite level of balance in the back for a tryst of bitter hops green and fresh with bitter burnt chocolate and nutty malts. Refreshing and thirst-inducing. Dry tobacco leaf of cigar and pipe regard flitters around the edges and tinges my breath. Green wood and green bark lurks in the back, observing more than partaking.

Final Thoughts: once more the roving brewer strikes a home-run in my tasting book. Mikkeller is truly a brewmaster of finesse, ingenuity, and a dab of eccentricity which I am all the more happy to indulge in with each and every beer. Bring it on, I say.

16.9 oz bottle.  Pours a deep brown with clear golden brown edges.  There is a moderate tan head that lasts through the first quarter of the glass and leaves partial lace.  Very pleasant aroma of rich sweet malt, coffee, and chocolate.  The flavor is roasted malt with just a bit of coffee.  An ash flavor develops and builds to the finish before subsiding.  Light bitterness at the finish as well.  A very solid and interesting brown ale.

Chestnut brown, slightly opaque.  Pours with a very thick, pillowy head that dissipates gradually and foamy lacing that climbs the side of the glass.  Aroma of sweet chocolate and spices.  Taste of unsweetened chocolate with a slight bitterness, followed by a mocha finish and a cappucino like aftertaste.  Chest warming alcohol feel, a very enjoyable brew overall,
Color marrone, aroma intenso fruttato e luppolato. Al palato è amara ma equilibrata, molto luppolo, note di nocciola e cioccolato, fruttata. il finale è un lungo  amaro luppolato. Speciale!

Bottle. Clear, dark amber color with some head. Amazing aroma, immediately thought of lychee. Next to this exotic fruit aroma, theres an overall sweetness thats stunning. Surprised by the taste; a strong fruit smell, but a taste of (weak) coffee and burnt malts. Medium body and a bitter hop finish. Shame the aroma does not return in the flavor to balance the finish a bit. Very decent beer for low % of alcohol.

This beer promises a lot on the first smell. Lychee and other tropical fruits, candied fruit, ripe melon. Wonderful. The beer is (dry?)hopped quite aggressively and the bitterness is a bit on the overwhelming side. Theres a nice hint of coffee. The taste doesnt deliver on the sweet notes you get in the aroma. 
This style definitively has potential, but in this beer the balance is a bit off.
Dark brown with light brown head - aroma of roasted malt -. same roasted malt body - good

Spicy hop aroma fragrance with notes of roasted malt, chocolate and orange. The taste is soft and slightly spicy with a marked hop aroma and a clear carbonation. The flavor is roasted malt, oats, chocolate, hops and cloves. Good and a bit dry after bitter. A good and nice beer, but it lacks some malts that can complete and highlight the rich taste of hops!
50cl bottle. Dark brown with a huge tan head. Roasty aroma with dark chocolate and coffee. Flavour is roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee and some hops. Medium-bodied and very smooth mouthfeel.

Ölen är mörk och har stort skum, men doften tycker jag är ganska svag och tråkig. Humle är stort sätt det enda jag känner, och jag blir sittande och tänka på om det har gått lite sport i att använda mycket Centennial och Armarillo-humle numera? Smaken är lite i tunnaste laget och har enbart svaga toner av choklad och lite rostiga toner som jag tycker borde vara mycket tydligare.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2011 Bottle. Very dark red/brown with a large, creamy tan head. Aroma: fruit, caramel. Taste: caramel, tropical fruit, pineapple, coffee, dark chocolate. Medium to full mouthfeel. Nice!
The bottle I had yesterday was much hoppier, and felt much fresher. Are they still brewing it?
Aroma: lots of American hops. Taste: hops, coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, medium bitter, long hoppy finish with some grapefruit.

50 cl bottle. Dark brown, almost black in colour with light brown head that is quite longlasting, leaving a nice lacing on the glass. Coffee and toffee aromas. Flavour of coffee, chocolate and hops. A bit sharp when cold, but evens out when getting warmer. Over all a good beer that is refreshing and gets one relaxed.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2010 A brown-red ale with light brown thick and long head. Aroma start with a hoppy hint (citrus!) and then malty and fruity. Light caramel too. Chocolate end. Taste is lightly sweet, and average bitterness. Coffee ending.
Rather strange sensation. Dominating hops strangle the other flavours.
Not so interesting in my opinion. 
Update:
Second bottle was better, more balanced flavours. Still too much hoppy, but more complex range of sensations.

Smooth, chocolatey, and hints of liqorice. The commercial description (for once) almost nails this beer. The aroma reminds me of hot chocolate, but theres a slightly "clashing" note there from the hops which works fine in the flavour, but lets the aroma down.

Snifter. Lots and lots of head. Dark brown ale. Strong hoppy, slightly fruity aroma. I am enjoying this one room temperature warm. I really like the aroma. Roasty, hoppy, bitter, chocolaty and coffee-like flavours. Dry aftertaste with a hint of licorice in it. I burb and more hop flavours return into my mouth. I am surprised that this one doesnt have more alcohol in it because the hoppiness would cover up the taste of it nicely and maybe give it a little bit more kick.

Appearance: Brown/reddish colour, big brown head, lacing. 
Aroma: Hoppy, fruity, chocolate, coffee.
Flavour: -ll-
Mouthfeel: smooth small bubbles.
Total: Very good.

(from a bottle @ The Old Toad Mikkeller Beer Dinner) Clear brown color with a thin white head. Mildly nutty aroma with some hints of hops and caramel. Bitter and hoppy at the start with some light caramel and nut flavors nearing the middle and a bitter finish. Was kind of expecting more.
Malty roasted aroma with medium bitter taste. Medium body with a meium sharp after taste I do not like so much. Boring beer, the first Mikkeller beer I do not like.

Bitter with a after taste of coffe
Malt: bread
Yeast/Bacteria: dough
Other: honey
Color: black
Head: rocky, brown
Initial: light bitterness, light sweetness
Finish: salty, heavy bitterness
Finish Duration: long
Body: light
Texture: thin
Carbonation: flat
Pours dark brown with tan head dark chocolate & coffee nose bitter velvety chocolate taste bitter smooth finish very tasty hopper then is expect.

33 cl bottle, pours ruby with a huge creamy head, lots of lacings, nice head retention, aroma of coffee, pine, chocolate and grass, taste is chocolate, pine, coffee and grass as well, alot more hop dominated then I expected but a very good beer.
Rødbrun med brunligt skum, masse af kaffe og chokolade, samtidig med meget grapefrugt som en IPA. Dejlig hybrid øl.

Bottle. Pours a deep darm brown with only a little head. Great hopping with chocolate and caramel in the maltign to complment each other. The nose is great and so is the mouth.. but the long lasting and wonderful finish is the big winner. Great tribute to a geat character.
Very hoppy coffee smell. The full taste of hop takes the upperhand, in the back you can still taste the coffee but this is rather limited.

Thank you Erwin to share this bottle with me. Pours out brown, beige good sized head. Looks great and the head holds good. Smell is hoppy and some spices. Some caramel seems to come up. Some weird sweetness also. Hoppy, cacao, spices, bitter and light sour taste. Ok beer, but misses a boost, some extra taste besides the overpowering biterness.
33 cl bottle, Sheffield, UK. Deep chocolaty brown, heavy roasted malt aroma with a spicy back. Hops on the first sip, almost sour, with a long dry finish.

330 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu. Vintage. Rated @ 6.3.2010.
Hazy reddish brown colour with a medium-sized off-white head. Pleasant hoppiness on the aroma with licorice, coffee and dry fruits. Very espresso-like taste with notes of dry and aged hops, roasted malts and cocoa.  Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. Enjoyable.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Opaque dark brown beer with tall beige head, very good looks. Aroma and taste share quite the same characteristics: dark chocolate, coffee, hops. Badly balanced, bitterness dominates this brew too much.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors. 
Aroma: There is a nice touch of lightly roasted malt, a nice nuttiness and an earthy herbal hop note. 
Appearance: It pours dark brown with a large, foamy, off-white head.  Good head retention and spotty lacing left behind. 
Taste: All the attributes from the nose are present in the taste plus some cocoa notes.  The hops are a little more forward than usual in the style, but its a nice switch.  
Palate: Medium bodied but it feels lighter due to a higher than normal level of carbonation.  The finish is slightly bitter and nutty. 
Overall: A nice departure from the rather plain and usual terms of a brown ale.  The earthy hops add a welcome dimension and this brew is true to the Mikkeller style.  Definitely worth getting your hands on.

Has a dark brown pour with a creamy white foamy, bubbly head. It has almost of a oily lacing that runs down the side of the glass very slowly. The carbonation is pretty strong/tight with a nice head retention. Has a chewy type of mouthfeel that hits you right in the back of the jaw. The aroma had hints of roasted nuts, coffee bean, and a smokey essence to it. The flavor is somewhat bitter on the back end and sweet in the front. One of the better browns that Ive had.
Huge tan head over a deep brown-red body. Obvious hops, nuts, liquorish. Bitter taste, very dry aftertaste. Lots of flavour. No easy drink but well worth it. Expensive. (33 cl bottle, 3,75 EUR)
500 ml bottle. Dark brown with tanned head. Very hoppy and nutty aroma, some maltiness. Nutty, fruity flavours with nice hops. Nice brown ale.
Pours a brown color with huge white head. Nose has touches of malt, nuts, and hops. The taste is very nutty cocoa, with a finish that tastes a bit like caramel.

Bottle.Pours brown with a nice tan head.Aroma of coffee ,sweet malt ,roasted malt and american hops.Flavor is coffee,roasted malts,caramel and fruity ale yeast.Meidium body,soft carbonation,firm bitterness.Nice!

(bottle) pours a clear dark ruby colour with a tall dense off-white head. aroma of tropical fruits and coffee, with a hint of caramel, fudge and roasted malts, blends rather nicely. flavour is mostly toasted malts, with notes of grain, coffee, bubblegum and a lingering caramelly herbal-hoppy finish. medium-bodied with smooth carbonation.

500 ml bottle. Deep dark reddish brown colour, creamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and berries. The flavour is roasted, with coffee and chocolate, and a nicely bitter, dry finish.

33 cl bottle. Pours dark brown with a brown head. Aroma is roasty malt and hop with a hint of chocolate. Flavor is hoppy and sweet with a strong bittersweet chocolate and coffee finish. Medium body with medium carbonation.
bomber.  pours a dark brown with an off white head.  aroma is big roasted aroma with caramel dark berries, then roasted malts.  t:big roasted malt flavor, caramel, great hop presence, dry finish

On tap at flying saucer. Pours a very dark brown with a medium creamy light tan that lasts awhile leaving sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a light roasted malt and nuts. Medium mouthfeel with a bitter hop upfront with light hop and a nice lingering bitter finish. A good brown ale from mikkeller.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2014 Pours a nice deep brown with a beige head. Aroma of coffee, caramel, dark fruits and some nugget. Taste of cocoa beans, hops and some chocolate in the aftertaste. I felt this had a flavour gap right in the middle where it got a little watery.

Red brown, big dense head, creamy coloured. Aroma has malts, barley, caramel, nutmeg and leather. Bitter taste, a bit chocolate-like, mocca. Medium-bodied, with roasted malts also in the taste. Somewhat bitter and dry finish.
Bottle 50 cl. Black with a big rocky head. Aroma; Dark fruits with some coffee sence. taste; medium bitter...

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2010 27.07.2010, 0,5l Bottle. Dark brown colour. Aroma is dark with rich maltflavours. There is a strong flavour of hops thate reminds me of juniperus. Aftertaste is lasting and I think this is a very nice and smooth Brown Ale.

Extremely dark brown pour with a one finger beige head. The aroma is spicy rye type grains with hints of chocolate, roasted malts, bready dough, orangepeel, and fennel. The flavor is a chocolate-roast bomb with prevailing citrus notes throughout. The palate is thick and rich for the style with creamy effervescence and a semi dry finish from hints of chalky roast.

Pours a deep dark brown colour with a big off-white head. Aroma is of roasted malts, toast, grains, chocolate, slight coffee and a sweet brown sugar like scent. Taste is quite malty up front and filled with roasted chocolate and has a nice bitterness towards the finish. Full body, average carbonation and thick on the palate. Overall a very nice beer, not my favourite brown ale but pretty good.
scura buona schiuma piuttosto persitente naso tostato e luppolato americano in contemporaneo in bocca prima tostaure cioccolato caffe poi luppoli secca medio amaro

Whoa! This is an overload on the senses. You can tell that there really is a decent amount of malt in there but theres enough hops to mistake it for an IIPA by the nose. Poured with a huge almost 2 inch head of nice creamy foam on top. Still cant tell of the lacing, it hasnt died down yet. Is indeed very brown, not too dark to see that. After a few more sips the malts start to come out at the beginning but wow do the hops ever pick up and take off with it. This is quite good, but I really couldnt call it a brown ale if I brewed it. It would have to be called India Brown Round (trip) or something, IBR for short; when you drink it it seems like a misrepresentation of brown ale to score this well in that category. After my mouth has gotten used to it the hops now seem more balanced against the malts but this is a beer for all the hop heads out there. Its more like an excuse for a hop head to get a beer that says brown ale on it. I love it, but I would have liked it better in my no hops is too much days.

Chocklate, fidges fruits citrus rosted malts aroma. Pours black with huge tanned head leaving lacing on glass. Malty and very hoppy flavor with tones of chocolate and fruits. Acidy sour crisp on palate. Finishes first sour crisp turning into tart bitter hoppy and citric aftertaste. 8,5,8,3,16

Poured ruby-brown with a huge beige head, that showed no intention of even collapsing. Strong hoppy scent of mouthwatering grapefruit and pine during pouring. Roasted malts, chocolate and a hint of coffee hiding behind the massive amount of hops. A bit fruity at the same time, reminds me of plums mostly. Hoppy bitterness with a little bit of brown sugary sweetness balances the taste out. Tons of carbonation makes this beer an active one, with nice hoppy aftertaste. Another great one from Mikkeller!

750 ml bottle brewed at De Proef. 

The beer pours a hazy brown color with a tan head. The aroma is earthy hops with some toffee and chocolate. I also get something that resembles celery, but I am not sure why. The flavor is bitter chocolate with some earthy and dirt-like hops. I also get some caramel malt and some burnt malt. The aftertaste is chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel and low to medium carbonation.
330ml bottle. The color is a dark ruby with a beige head. The aroma or lack of it is bitter. The taste is bitter sweet roasted malt, hops yeast and berries.

750 ml. corked caged bottle- Pours dark brown with a huge tan head, aroma is somewhat disappointing, kind of grainy. The flavor is thankfully better than the aroma, but not excellent either, full flavor with some nuttiness and caramel malts with a bitterness that was unexpected, but  still the whole thing seems very average, this beer was not cheap and I feel like I kind of wasted my money. Your average brown ale from any American brewery is just as good or better, and you can get a whole 6 pack for around 7 or 8 bucks, this costed me $14.99, but at least I got to rate it.

Served on draft at Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA, 6/21/10. Pours a clear dark ruby color with a medium sized creamy brown head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and a hoppy finish. The taste is chocolate, cocoa, bitter leafy and citrus hops, berries and roasted malts. Medium-full bodied.

Bottle, shared with my very good friend Barry. Pours medium to dark brown, this could almost be in Porter country in terms of the color. Thick pale tan head, great lacing. Nose is chocolate, soy sauce, sweet toffee/caramel, raisins, tobacco, spice, wood, and baked goods. Flavors are spicy chocolate, sweet toffee, nice woody character, earthy, mildly smoky on the finish. I could easily drink this every day!
Dark brown pour, small tan head.  Toasted malt, nuts, chocolate, oats, and herbals bitterness.  Balanced brown, on the stronger side.  I am not a big brown ale fan, but this is decent.

More like an American Brown I think. Poured with a great light tan foamy frothy thick head that lasts and some lace. Color is dark cherry wood. Aroma is roasty malty cocoa, coffee dark ripe cherries yeast. Flavors the same. Body is good expansive and round with good carbonation. Finish is like flavor and medium to long in length. Excellent beer. Session beer.

Draught at Salhojankadun Pub, Tampere, Finland.
Dark brown colour with small tan head.
Fresh hops and wood in aroma.
Roasted malt, chocolate, dark hops and mild coffee in flavour.
Hoppy aftertaste. Not that dark after all. I was gladly surprised of its hoppiness.

Draft at Crane Alley in Urbana, IL. Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma of cookie and wet grains. Lighter side of medium bodied with soft to medium carbonation, with a homebrew like mouthfeel. Flavor of nutty malts, brown sugar, and wet grains with a very low bitterness. Moderate amount of sweetness with just a hint of tanginess. I find brown ales fairly boring, but this one is not bad.

Big bottle, shared with my in-laws on Fathers Day poker night. Dark brown with a very lively bubbly brown head that compacts and retains well. Intriguing spicy roasty aroma, faint coffee. Flavours of chocolate, musty cork, spices, dark fruits, and faint coffee. Bitter and tart at the same time. Very interesting and tasty. More of a belgian style brown.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Dark brown thick foamy head. Looks great. Very bold hoppy aroma. very floral. Flavour is very complex. bold and hoppy with notes of chocolate and coffee in the finish. It almost smells like juniper berries. this is an amazing and complex beer. Great. I feel like I should grow an affro.
Dark brown, kinda black, nice tan sticky head.  Aroma is chocolate, chewy, sweet malt.  Taste is coffee, chocolate, dark fruit, roasty.

Bottle. Light brown pour with some light tan head. Some cocoa and roasted  nutty malt aromas. Bitter malt finish with some light hops and nutty malt background. Kind of expensive for just a brown ale.
Amazing brown ale. Roasted malts, smoky aromas, chocolate flavours plentiful. Hints of licorice. Some hops bitter, but not much. A great brown ale overall.

Tap at Rattle n Hum. Pours brown with a creamy, beige head. Highly roasty aroma. Lots of brown sugar in the flavor, along with notes of molasses, chocolate, and light caramel. Bitter, roasty and dry in the finish. Medium bodied with average carbonation. An excellent Brown Ale.

Bottle at home. Clear deep reddish brown color with a huge off-white, creamy, foamy, head that leaves loads of lacing. Aroma of citrus and grapefruit hops, some coffee and a hint of licorice. Flavor is bitter with strong coffee, some floral hops, chocolate and more coffee and some licorice in the finish. Very creamy texture and a nice body for only 6% abv. Very lively carbonation as well. Great brew.

Bottle at 4:20 at RBESG Rome. Dark brown colour, beige head. Aroma of sweet caramel, toffee, nuts, grapefruity hops, haagse hopjes. Flavour is sweet, malty, light coffee, nutty, strong hoppy bitter finish. Medium bodied.

750ml brown bottle, corked. BB date 03/02/11. Dark brown pour, full and stiff, thick tan head with good retention. Sticky creamy lacing. Chocolate nose, some coffee, some hops. Coffee and chocolate notes up front with orangey slightly fruity hop flavours. Long leafy bitter aftertaste alongside some dry roasty coffeeish malt, a bit of earth.  Medium bodied, medium carboantion. A big brown, not exactly in balance, but thats not really a bad thing here.
Coffee colored, coffee transparency, tinted lacing. Strong sturdy flavor of really dark chocolate and pine needles, some grapefruit, prunes and oaky side tones, Very hoppy, very nice.

Draft. Pours deep amber brown with a beige head. Roasted malty aroma, with a light sweetness and some toasted bread. Nice roasty/toasty malt flavor, with some coffee and citric/floral hops. Very well balanced.
tap - toasty roast, cookie and some spice and pepper. cinnamon, nuts (walnuts). finishes a bit astringent. PRetty good.
Draught from R&H.  Poured a dark brown with mild whitish head. Nuts and malts and chocolate aroma, complex body and cleanish finish.  A great brown.

Rena tyngdlyftningen för sinnena. Beskan är så tät att den kan användas som isolering samtidigt som det finns en del "luft" också, mellanrum som andas och gör upplevelsen ytterst angenäm. Rekommenderas.

The aroma is chocolate, nuts, roasty, light fruit.  The appearance is a nice deep brown, opaque, tan head, like a stout.  The flavor is chocolate, nuts, brown sugar sweetness.  Very good.  The finish is piney hops.  Medium/thick in body, again more like a stout.  Excellent.

Ok, its brown, but so dark it feels like a stout. Very much hoppier then others in style, very american with plenty of fruits and a nice bitterness to finish it off. A very nice beer Ill have more of in the future.

Bottle.

Brown color with an off-white head.

The aroma is of toasted malts, bread and hops.

The flavor is sweet with a light malty character and quite a lot of hoppy aromas. Notes of coffee and chocolate. Ends bitter and dry with notes of bread and hops.

Medium body, fizzy carbonation.

Well it goes down.

Bouteille de 500 ml. Arômes très intéressants de houblon résineux et de chocolat. Robe brune foncée et opaque, belle mousse beige et effervescence assez forte pour le style. En bouche, le corps est relativement mince, mais de belles notes maltées et chocolatées accompagnent le houblon américain (résine, citron). Finale sèche de cacao et moyennement amère. Presque une Black IPA.
bottle from Bierzwerg. Deep bronw colour, mid-sized beige head. Aroma of coffee. Dry mouthfeel, rather light-bodied with flavours of espresso coffee and bitter chocolate.

330ml bottle. Pours opaque deep brown with a rocky yellowish-tinged white head that lasts and laces nicely. Ample creamy roasted caramel nose with notes of citrus, cocoa and coffee. Flavoursome rich dark roasted malt palate with a mildly spicy bitter hop finish. Full bodied with a tingly mouthfeel. Elegant and classy.

Pours a hazy brown body with an off-white head. Smell is dark malts and hints of licorice. Taste is toast, some coffee notes, cough syrup hops and bun dough. A very nice and just-enough-complex brown ale, without tipping over into another genre. Loved the movie as well, one of Tarantinos most underrated films. So cool of Mikkeller to brew a tribute to it. :-)

330ml bottle shared with patrick. thx for the share man!! pours brown with a small tan head. roasty nose, with chocolate and cara malt. the hops really come through in the flavour and bitter out the finish nicely. really tasty session brown ale.
Draught. Pours dark nutty brown with large, creamy, off-white head. Taste has bitterness, palate has a dry mouthfeel, lightly astringent finish. Aromas have herbs, burnt malts.
Tasty brown ale. Pour is dark brown. Chocolate and vanilla nose. Taste is much the same. Rated 4/15/10

Dark hazy brown, thick creamy beige head. Aroma of caramel, fruit, floral hops, oat, burnt malt. Taste is bitter up front with more burnt malt and sweet chocolate malt also. Lots of flavor for a relatively low alc percentage. Thick body, soft carbonation.

Bottle from Berts Bierhuis. Pours a dark brown beer with a good white head.  Medium carbonation after pouring. Hoppy aroma with hints of grapefruit and citrus. Taste is dominated by the hops. Later some coffee and chocolate notes. Good beer.

Pours a dark brown, almost black with a reddish tint. Big beige slow fading head. Hop, malt, pine aroma. Flavor is mostly hop, with bits of coffee, chocolate, and malt. Crisp and medium bodied. Dry roast, hop, malt finish. This is a somewhat unique brew with the big hop flavor. I like it. But if you dont like a heavy hop brew, you will want to avoid this one. The last few different brews I have had were pale or mild ale. This one is at the other end of the spectrum.

Little to no aroma - served too cool.

Some coffee, some chcolate, lots of hop.

Simple finish,.

Fair b alance, not interesting.

Too hoppy for a brown ale, for my taste. Purchased on tap at ørsted ølbar.

Bottle.

A - Dark, murky reddish-copper brown color. Average sized creamy off-white to light beige colored head. Decent retention and a bit below average speckled lacing left.

S - Pretty strong coffee along with some herbal/floral hop aroma. Some chocolate and cocoa smells are in the background along with some nutty, earthy, and woody smells. Fair amount of malty smell is also drifting between the foreground and the background.

T - Strong kick of coffee and to a slightly lesser extent chocolate right away. Then some of that herbal/floral and some earthy hop flavors come in that provide a fairly bitter taste. Mid-sip some more of the earthy/woody flavors start to come out along with some grainy malts and more coffee and (again to a lesser extent) chocolate. These provide for more of a burnt/roasted bitterness. Once the hops present themselves, they never really leave, just go more in the background. Fairly bitter beer, especially for a Brown Ale.

M - Medium body with slightly below average carbonation. Drying but provides a sharp kick.

D - The flavors are enjoyable, but they can get to be a bit too much and overbearing. I dont know if I would want to drink more than one in a night. 

Notes: Interesting take on a Brown Ale, as this is quite bitter. Both from roasted flavors and from a good amount of hops. The coffee flavor is pretty dominant throughout but not so much that it completely hides the other flavors. Nice beer that I enjoyed, but I dont know if I will try again, probably if I find it for a good price I would.

Pours dark brown with a light brown fluffy head that nicely laces the glass while it slowly settles. Pine grapefruit and herbal hops in nose. Citrus and a faint malty sweetness with an excellent bitter punch. Not so brownish perhaps but still a very nice hoppy and bitter ale.

Bottle. Pours brown-red with a golden head. Fresh citrus hoppy aroma. Some chocolate in the background. The taste is also hopbased and the "normal" brown ale qualities is doing its thing in the background. A little thin. A nice beer but not a very good brown ale.

Bottle from Systembolaget.

Pours chocolate brown with a tan head.

Good tasting beer, fresh with lots of hops, slightly bigger body, and obviously a lot darker apperance, than a IPA.

Smells very much like an IPA, the apperace is more red than I expected. I am adding an extra point for the way the vapor stays in the bottle for a little while and then slowly fumes out. Almost like a gun that has just been shot. Also tastes much like an IPA, but with nice smooth flowery bitterness.

Not at all what I expected, but very good
Lovely brown with nice head. Aroma hop and elderberry. Taste bitter hop. Body & text medium. carb average. Bitter hop finish.

Really powerful nose of sweet chocolate malts and syrupy figs/raisins.  Pours muddy deep brown with no head.  The sweetness is very well balanced in the flavour - not as overpowering as the nose might suggest by any means.  In fact, the balance is near perfect with bitter hoppy tartness bickering pleasantly with sweet coffee liqueur malt; the whole leading to a long, bitter and exceptionally moreish finish.  Very nice indeed.

Deep dark brown, red glow, medium tanned head. Aroma is very hoppy, grapefruit, orange peel with a faint hint of coffee. Quite bitter flavour of fruity and floral hops. Long lingering bitterness with faint coffee at the end.
Nice one.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2011 Pours dark brown with a big beige head, a very good-looking beer. Lots of hoppy aromas, flowers, pine-needles, resin, herbs. Theres chocolate, coffee and roasted malts there as well, but not as appearant as the hops. At first I thought the malt and hops didnt really come together well, but after a second chance I got it. Taste is dry with a medium bitterness.

Pours a brown color with a large white head, leaving some lacing. Aroma of grassy, spicy and citrusy hops, coffee, light chocolate and a hint of liquorice. Flavour is mostly coffee, chocolate, liqurice and grassy, spicy, almost herbal hops. Hints of grapefruit too. Rather bitter finish. Feels very dry, the carbonation is average to lively, and the texture is a bit oily. Mediumbodied.

Another great beer from Mikkeller. Bottle from Utobeer, London. Poured with a lovely toffee coloured head. Smell of coffee and obviously loads of hops. Lovely taste, lots of hops, nice coffee and chocolate bitterness. Lots of depth, get all the chocolate and coffee first then left with a dry bitter hop finish. Highly recommend this beer.

Bottle, 2010-03-26, Göteborg
AR: caramel, wee roasted malts
AP: dark brown body,+ 5 cm high steady rocky ofwhite head, lowely curtains
F: full body, rough bitterness, the chocolate is there but not as great as expected, a bit vanilla is discoverd in the finish

Citrusy aroma smells like lemonjuice thats been left out for a day. Looks ok but not as thick and black u would like. Good head however. Taste is citrus. Sour and bitter citrus.Thin mouthfel.Astringent, can´t believe the high scores on this one. Bad bottle?-but i dont think so. Can´t recommend this beer.
Beautiful, big brown ale. Lots of malt, hops and fruity almost Belgium esters. My favourite Mikkeller!

Pours light brown, translucent, with off white head.

Nose has a sweet n sour note in it, wet paper coffee filter, and light artificial citrus.

Palate lacks many brown ale characteristics such as the pronounced roasted flavors. Instead the hops take over, with a cola like quality in place.

Finish is funky and unpleasant.

Pours hazy brown with big light-beige head; slightly roasted aroma, of cocoa and hops; medium body, moderate carbonation; flavor is pretty bitter and dry with notes of cocoa and coffee, especially in the aftertaste. That harsh hop bitterness felt a bit out of place here. But then again what can you expect from Mikkeller.

(750ml). Wild milky mud brown with a little touch of caramel and very tan head that is lacy tall and lasting. Aroma is roasty caramel booze and molasses and licorice and hops of light grapefruit. Flavor is spicy, roasty caramel, chocolate, and lighter earthiness and some sweeter tones. Finish is dull bitter and chocolate.

750ml bottle. Pours a muddy dark brown with a huge clumpy beige head that has great retention and oodles of lacing. The aroma is relatively soft with roasted malts, spicy grains and earthy hops. The flavor is more of the same, sweet roasted grains with a spicy complexity, molasses and some nutty hops. The palate is somewhat thin, but appropriate for the style. The finish is medium in duration and dry. Overall: A very sessionable brown, much enjoyed.

Caramel, coffee, roasted malt aroma,s pop up from the light brown head of this ruby beer. Wait theres more, slightly hoppy, licorice and than its time to taste the beer. A bit sharp in the mouth. Slightly sweet but not as sweet as the aroma should suspect, and than ... the hops kick in like a mule. Surprising beer you never know whats coming next, just like the movie.
But when the beer gets a bit warmer,when the heat is on,  you can already guess whats coming,... the hops are invading.

Bottle, dirt cheap from Rhythm & Booze, Brigg. Deep brown almost black, thin but lasting off white head and low condition. Excellent sweet chocolate, bitter coffee and hefty hop resins in the nose, fruity initialy in the mouth but quite thin with some background tartness, bitter roastiness, a muted flowery hoppiness and a hint of chocolate, lingering bitter finish with some berry fruitiness and a gentle undercurrent of hop resin

My first ever Danish micro and considering the Dane brewing scene is pretty vibrant, I was looking forward to this beer.  I enjoyed it on reflection . A pretty solid Brown ale, with out making me that excited.   Aromatic ,hoppy nose ,mixed with some roast malt is kinda American in vibe.  A roasty and chocolatey tastin ale.  Very sessionable and eazy .  This style does bore me either way.

Botlle 33 cl. Pours a cloudy brown with a thick, medium-sized off-white head and an aroma of fruity syrup, sweet malts, maybe some light chocolate, but almost no hops. The taste has lots of malts, but they are pretty plain in taste. Theres also some sweet chocolate and not too sweet fruits (maybe plums). After a while the hops come kicking in and all the sweetness disappears.  Its a very nice beer, but I guess with a little less hops it could have been more complex.

Jackie Brown pours a cloudy amber with a bubbly beige head.  The transition of flavors on the palate, from toasty malt and nutella until the hops kick in, is gradual and wonderful.  I think the beer lacks depth in the malt flavor for a brown ale, which I first thought was the big hop profile masking everything else.  Regardless, its a very nice beer.

Aroma molto luppolato che va a coprire molto le note di malto tostato...anche se è un aroma molto gradevole...
Colore ambrato\marroncino semilimpido...schiuma compatta densa sul marroncino...
Una volta lasciata scaldare nel bicchiere , le note di malto aumentano esponenzialmente....
Al palato , un amaro che rimane persistente fino a sprigionare delle note accese di malto...
Bottle, Beers of Europe. A full on chocolate and coffee experience. Roast malt evident but bitter hops take over to give a sharp, very English, porter flavour. Woody, earthy and lip smacking.

Bottle: deep chestnut-amber coloured, smaller loose beige head; perfect illusion of freshly ground coffee detectable in the dry roast-malty nose; dry bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied; lingering dry bitter-malty finish with a coffeeish aftertaste. Nice brew......
Hop is dominating the aroma, although a slight hint of caramel and malts is notable. Is is a very tasteful brown ale, that leans a bit towards the IPA-feeling, which makes it a refreshing brown ale.

750ml bottle, corked & caged, via secret santa trade. pours a dark, cola brown with a huge, fluffy, tan head and thick, clingy lace. aroma is quite good with dark roasted malts, charred wood, roast nuts, and sweet brown sugar with hints of earthy hops, spruce, and cocoa powder. flavor is delicious and is actually hoppy up front with earthy and herbal hops with a touch of citrus that quickly transitions to big, roasted, chocolatey malts, hazelnut, almond, and coffee with a roasted, nutty finish. palate is medium bodied with bubbly carbonation. overall, a very nice brown ale.

I like brown ales but think there are a lot of bad ones out there.  However, I found Jackie Brown to be a quite enjoyable glass.  That said, its definitely hoppy for a brown.  Again, personally, I enjoy this aspect, but a purist would probably consider it off-style.  Its quite a bit more fruity than nutty or roasty, though those flavors are present if muted.  Theres a healthy chocolate note, which mixes well with the grapes, apricots and grapefruit rind hop notes that dominate.  The beer pours a dark brown with a touch of red.  The head is a pillow of khaki foam.  It seems rather dry for a brown but I might just be tasting the hops there.  Enjoyable.
VEyr nice and first time I have it out of a bottle. Nce shape and head in it too. NOt so browny as other more comercial ones.

750 ml from redlight redlight.  Pours a cloudy brown with a thin tan head.  The nose is very subtle but good with a slightly funky slightly wood aroma.  The flavor is also subtle but even better.  Hints of vanilla and cocoa really add an extra complex sweetness while the finish is malty, crisp and tart.  Probably best to let it warm a little bit as the flavors all become bolder.  Excellent beer but whos surprised when it comes to Mikkeller.

Aroma is malty up front, sweet finish in the smell.  Color is a dark like a porter but more brown than black.  the head is tan in color.  Taste is malty up front, a little hoppy in the finish with hints of chocolate and smoke.  love  it

Aroma is sugary with cinnamon, milk chocolate, spice and toffee. Smells amazing. 
Flavours start out dry (and stay dry). Nice tangy/sour hints with a mild aftertaste of coffee. Huge amounts of hops last in your mouth forever.
Oddly, quite a crisp mouthfeel contrary to the aromas. Very Nice!

Bottle. A very malty aroma, some roasted aromas with dark chocolate and coffee. The head is small, creamy and brown with a short duration. The body is nearly black. The taste started very bitter, then it gets really dry in the mouth with a lot of coffee. The finish is a little bit sour. The body is medium strong and creamy- dry with a soft carbonation.

330 ml bottle.  Pours dark chocolate brown, with a cocoa head.  It has a great nutty aroma, rich full flavor of roasted nuts, coffee, and a sweet herbal note.  Medium body, lasting finish, and packed with flavor

Bottle: &nbsp Chocolate brown, slight ruby, thick and hazy. &nbsp Its like soup! &nbsp Huge pillowy light beige head, nice lacing. &nbsp Very muddy looking. &nbsp Soft roasted malt nose, subtle hop, earthy. &nbsp Not too big on 

the tongue. &nbsp Certainly roasty, just the right amount, but not as malty as I would have hoped. &nbsp Almost on the thin side. &nbsp Good flavor, but falls flat on the tongue. &nbsp Lingering hop notes. &nbsp Good, just wished it had 

a bit more body.

Batch 60, 33cl bottle: This Brown Ale looks darker than some Porters. Aromas of chocolate and cocoa mix with a hoppiness that reminds me of freshly cracked spruce needles and freshly cut apricots - really nice. Espresso-like roasted malt flavour with woody, grassy and subtle alcoholic notes. Very rough bitterness and roasty acidity with a mild carbonation, mouthfeel is actually quite light. Decent beer, although its a bit over the top on the roastiness and bitterness for my liking.

Bottle at Hashigo Zake. Pours deep ruby red with a massive fizzy head. Big hoppy citrus nose with underlying chocolate.
Initial grapefruity hop bitterness progresses into a nice roasty chocolate. Hops make a comeback for a bitter finish. A confusing but amazing beer.
75cl, Danish brewery, from Slijterij van Bergen Eindhoven, complex brew, yet easy to drink, balanced, hazy, good head, good brew

330ml bottle. Another great brew from Mikkeller. Poured a deep dark brown, bordering on black with a large rich creamy tan head. Wonderful coffee aromas assault the nose and are highlighted by strong burnt flavours that dominate the palate, sharp and bitter with a long finish.

Bottle. Pours a deep mahogany with a nice reddish tint around the edges. Huge dense persistent coffee coloured head. Plenty of nice lacing once the head disappears. Aromas of roasted nutty malt, chocolate and plenty of US hops. Flavours of dark chocolate, coffee and toasted malt upfront followed by the citrus and resiny pine from the hops. Finish is quite dry and bitter thanks to both the roasted malt and the hops. Definitely not what I expected but a good beer all the same.

33cl bottle. Pours a very dark brown with lighter edges, a creamy tan head with an oily, thickish lacing. Creamy milk chocolate aromas with notes of coffee and roasted malt and a hint of grassy hops in the background. Darker chocolate on the gonue with more coffee and roasted malts finishing with a dry, toasty, slightly burnt finish. Initially aggressive carbonation, slowly subsides to be quite smooth, medium body and a lovely lasting dry finish. Nice balance & bloody lovely overall. Rich & porterish.

50cl bottle from Barley Wine. Best before 2009-12-13. It poured a medium dark brown colour with a huge off-white creamy head that settled down slow in the glass. Some oxidation. Aroma is hoppy. Notes of coffee. The flavour is bitter, notes of hops, coffee and malts. Some liqorice as well. Medium long aftertaste. Id say this is closer to a porter than a brown ale, but its a nice beer overall.

Bottled 330ml. Quite pleasant nose with resiny hops being rather prominent. A hint of spring onion sneaking in unfortunately (which I found in some Mikkeller beers, most present in the warrior IPA). A touch of licorice showing up. And as you dig deeper, wow- lavender and rosemary emerge. Complex. Strong bitterness in the taste. Chocolatey on the swallow. Great bitter chocolatey finish.
Dark mahogany in color with a moderate, white head. Aroma of cocoa, vanilla and coffee.   Starts out with hops and finishes with a bit of chocolate.

14/11/2009. 33cl bottle from Hashigo Zake before heading down to see the All Whites qualify for the 2010 World Cup.  Milk chocolate and spice.  Malt character a little tired and the beer (I can only guess) has dried out a fair bit more than it would be at its best... leaving the hops a little harsh and grassy.  Still very pleasant but it didnt quite live up to the anticipation - but the football did!

(bottle, 33cl) Darkest brown colour with a light ruby shine and a small beige foamy head. Sweet and deep strongly roasted malt profile in the nose with notes of chocolate, coffee, liquorice, nettles and a tinge of fruity hops in the back. Moderately sweet and roasty bitter flavour, medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Quite dry mouthfeel, robust roast-malty taste with notes of milky mocha, chocolate, liquorice and an aromatic presence of subtle fruity hops in the background; pretty dry and roasty bitter and hoppy finish. Very nice, makes me think of a slightly diluted Imp. Stout. 15.XI.09

20th July 2008. Brown beer. Distinct chocloate tone but it jars against the very bitter hop finish. Better when it warms up a bit - doesnt clash quite as much but these flavours are uncomfortable bed fellows. 

Conscious of my comparatively low rating have since retried this beer but still fail to see why it averages 3.7.

Broen with an enourmous tan head - must be poured with extreme care.  Chocolatety malit aroma with pleanty of alcohol. Chocolate and crystal malt flavour with strong american hop bitterness.  Finosh is dry and bitter.

Poured a coffeeish dark brown. Nose is quite floral and sweet - like some type of candy. In the mouth was more sweetness with some good hops. Almost in IPA territory. Quite a good little beer but quite expensive for what it is.

Brown/red colour with a brown head. Fantastic and quite different aroma of coffea, licorice, smoke, roasted malt & hops.  First impression does not get any better. It has a taste of hops which is too strong in my opinion, but actually gives it a hint of IPA to the Brown Ale...An Indian Brown Ale maybe...
Has a loooonng aftertaste of coffea. Might be good with a dessert. A very interesting beer, but it smells & looks better than it taste even though the taste is good as well.

Bottle from Liquid Solutions.  Pours a clear dark brown color with a two-finger tan head and some lacing.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate, and roast.  Comes together well.  Flavor is good but a bit harsh from the coffee.  Besides coffee, chocolate, nuts roasted malt, licorice, and bittering hops are present.  Body is medium with a long bitter finish lasting on the palate.  Overall a very good coffee brown ale.

750ml bottle. Pours a clear, deep brown colored body with a reddish tint. Two-finger width, rocky, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a good amount of lacing. Lots of herbal, sprucey citrus hops on the aroma up front. If I dig a little deeper I get some weak chocolate, nuts, and roast, but not much. Flavor is an inherent earthy and herbal hop without much of a malt backing. There is a light nutty toast, chocolate, and roast, but not much. Finishes with a dry, slightly resiny citrus and lingers with lots of herbal bite for a good amount of time. A hint of astringent roast comes through in the finish as well. Medium body with a creamy carbonation. Overall, disappointing. Almost no sweetness to accompany the hops and barely a trace of roasty chocolate. Not a huge fan of this brown ale soley focussed on the herbal hops.

Bottle. Glossy tar with a woolly tan head tufting the glass; faint ruby glints against the light. Aroma straight grapefruit and lychee to begin with, blending into chocolate ice cream, Bovril and burnt toast. Slick, burnt and punching; grapefruit bitterness; high cocoa, tonic water and incinerated pistachio in a deep, resonating finish. Silky and integrated, especially the dregs. Very good. At least as good as Mostodolce Jacky Brown.
this has got a bit of age and travel but is still good. nose is dominated by bready chocolate. chocolate is still present in the flavour but there is also a good amount of tangy hoppiness and malt.
Bottle. Mahogony beer with a huge cream colored head. Toffee and light roast aroma. Nutty, toffee flavor with light hops. Medium bodied. Toffee, nuttiness, and light hops linger.

Not your traditional brown ale, but thats a good thing in m book.A lively head with lots of lacing. Lots of roasted malt and coffee in the aroma and in the flavor. Starts off with a bright, slightly fruity burst but then finishes with a very dry, hop/coffee bitterness. Very nice.

Pours a dark brown color with very slight amber edges when held to a light source and a huge frothy, pillowy light beige head. Excellent retention, only slowly fading to a lasting cap that leaves large chunks of soapy lacing on its way down.

Roasted coffee aroma with chocolate malt notes, licorice, oatmeal, caramel and hazelnut.

Once again the flavor is dominated by roasted malt with hints of oatmeal, roasted coffee, toffee, chocolate, burnt toast, caramel, nut and a subtle dry hoppy finish.

On tap at SBWF. There was nothing wrong with the beer. Looks and all that but the taste was a bit thin. Chocolate, caramel and coffee tones and some nuts. 

The beer not bad but neither exactly exciting. I thought the smell was more fun than flavor, although there was no strong fragrance.

Bottle:  The aroma consists of chocolate, roasted nuts, and hint of coffee.  It pours a hazy, bordering on cloudy, orangish-brown with a moderate khaki head with good retention.  The flavor starts with chocolate with a hint of roasted coffee in the background.  The finish is lightly nutty with a hint of piney hops. Light-medium bodied with somewhat soft carbonation.

750ml bottle, this Jackie has a brown pour with a more than two finger high head of light tan bubbles, generous effervescence, left lots of lacing on the glass, aromas of chocolate, toasted malt with a good malt sweetness, citrus hops, faint nut and earthy fragrances, the aroma reminds me of a Strong Ale, a dark brown Strong Ale with lots of hops,  of course the alcohol is not there for Strong Ale, flavors of roasted malt, faint chocolate and coffee with a herb hop bitterness, for me, there may have been a bit too much hop bitterness that may have gotten in the way of fully enjoying the malt, mouth feel is lively from the carbonation, some hop bitterness trails after the finish, if you like a well hopped Brown Ale, you will enjoy this, I was looking forward to a nice flavorful Brown Ale with a forward malt profile.

My 650ml bottle was 2.5 years old at Rhinoi, one year past official expiry. Semi-turbid light chestnut prown with clear gold-brown highlights, medium creamy tan head.Aroma of demerera dark honey and slight wet hay. Great body and feel to this beer! Amazing hops presence, complex malts feature chocolate raisin honey fig toffee dry cocoa and fresh baked biscuit. Very pleasant bitterness seems to accrue and become more prominent on the finish. My thjis has aged well, would love to compare fresh.

Decided to pick this 25.4 oz. bottle up at Greens on Ponce De Leon. Looking VERY good for a brown ale. Nice DARK brown color. Damn near opaque. Nice slight off-white head that eventually fades away. In my opinion, this is how an awesome brown ale should look. Fairly nice balance between the malts and hops in the aroma. A decent nut aroma coming through. Very pungent brew. I am not a fan of the fact that the hops are so present, but this might be a positive note on the flavor. The flavor is, in my mind, excellent. Nice nutty, roast, malty flavor. The hops provide an excellent backing to this beer. Nice subtle coffee flavor as well. I dont think they could have done a better job on a brown. This roast is absolutely amazing. The hops and roast are just the perfect combo. The coffee comes out more as the beer warms up. This beer is simply amazing.

Very dark brown with lasting light brown head. First impression of the aroma was slightly poo like till the sweetness and hops kick in. Great smell. The chocolate malts are evident in the flavour, nice amount of hops, little coffee and something sweeter like vanilla. Again, Im very impressed by a Mikkeller brew.

Mondial 2009, Montreal.  Translucent chestnut brown with a nice beige head.  There are some American hops in the aroma, along with roasted malt and toasted nuts.  The beer is brown sugar sweet, with nuts, roast, and chocolate all joining in.  Finishes with a hoppy bitterness.  Full and creamy.  Too hoppy to be a traditional brown ale, but very good nonetheless.
33cl bottle. Cleat brown body with small tan head. Very different from the old 50 cl bottle I tasted several years back. More watery and less coffee flavour.

Sample at JaBiers refrigerator reduction tasting on 08/15/09. This brew is a murky dark brown-amber color with a medium beige head that recedes slowly. Stringy lacing on the glass. Coffee and citrusy hops in the nose as well as some roasted malt. Medium body with a flavorful blend of roasted coffee and malt flavors as well as brown sugar, chocolate and hops. The finish is roasty with a lingering hops aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

Bottle at my refrigerator reduction tasting on 8/15/09.  Pours a clear brown with a thin tan head.  Malty aroma with some cranberry, hops and roast.  Bitter hop flavor up front that transitions nicely to a roasty coffee finish.

This beer rules! Its a roasty, chocolaty brown ale with hints of coffee and licorice. Being a Mikkeller brew the malts are inevitably complimented by a great amount of hop bitterness, aroma and flavour

Pours copper with ruby tints. Huge head showing great persistence and lacing.
Hops dominates aroma, theres some grapefruit, pine, quite spicy. Toasty/bready malt hiding underneath. I would have liked more nutty/toasty malt.
Same with the flavours: green citrus hops dominates over the sweetness of the toasty and crystal malts. Solid bitter finish (IPA strength), seems to be from a mix of hops and dark grains.
Body is too watery for my liking.

Bottle @ GBBF 2009. A dark brown colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of coffee malts with hops and some fruits. The taste of coffee with fruits. Its dry and bitter. Hints of vanilla. The aftertaste is bitter coffee, with some fruits.

Pours reddish brown with a wispy mostly maintained tan head. Notes of English hops, pine, caramel, toffee, and earthy malt. Full bodied, lightly sticky with soft carbonation. A very nice brown ale, I was quite impressed.

Bottle. Pours with a huge tan head over a brown body. Aroma of chocolate, hops and vanilla. Taste is bitter coffee, vanilla and chocolate. Some lingering cocoa powder. Light carbonation smoothish mouthfeel.
Pours a dark ruby tinted brown with a big off white head. Aroma is dominated by hops. Flavor is big and hoppy with light roast malt, hints of coffee and nuts with a dry finish.
Hoppy bouquet - medium body, soft carbonation, bitter. Pours nicely deep brown. Bitter finish. Enjoyed it.

BB 2-9-11.  Pours a nearly opaque, rusty brown color with a massive, khaki, creamy, fluffy, float-like head which lasts for a long while but does finally rescinds allowing me to take a sniff while showing some lace rings.  The nose is complex and fairly hoppy, especially for a brown ale, much like a brown IPA or pale; notes of centennial and simcoe hops with a rustic tone, some light floral, light orange peel, dark bread crust, roasted pecans, some malted notes, and light notes of kona coffee and chocolate; a lot going on in the nose but everything works well together.  The flavor is nice but not matching the nose, dry, hoppy flavor with some dry malt notes as well.  Noting a more-than-moderate, herbal hop bitterness and light coffee bitterness throughout with other notes of light dry grass, malted cocoa, light grapefruit peel, pecans, and similar bread crust notes.  Moving into the finish I get just hints of anise and dark chocolate.  Palate is a little watery, silky, less-than-medium, and soft to lively, oh yeah, and dry; silky and dry in the same palate??
